Great, I'm most familiar with Vanguard, they have excellent low expense ratio options, VTI is one of the lowest. I'm invested in a lot of pharma, Wellington fund with them at the moment.. have family in that industry, and as they put it "no shortage of sick people"
Vanguard offers a total market etf under $vti  and a broad bond etf under $bnd.  So for a young person can be something like 80% vti/20% bnd.
Might as well go VTI or ITOT or /r/investing.

I dropped 25k in split between VTI, VOO and then a bunch of dipshit random stocks (some meme stocks, fuck you mu and others) a few months ago.

VTI and VOO are both up a bit over 7%, my dipshit stocks are doing pretty well but I did some stupid shit like panic selling while getting my sealegs.

All in all I'm up 6% in a few months and it's not huge gainz but it's also safe and still lets me mess around with smaller stuff while still having 'padding'. 

TL;DR i'm not smarter than the market is what I've learned

Not really sure what you mean there. You performed a linear regression of price of MU on price of SPY and the result was that there is a weak linear relationship between these two variables, i.e. one is not a great predictor of the other. Pick more correlated tickers and you will get a better r squared. Try regressing VTI on SPY, for example.

Does **$VIX** count?  Or only tickers you can buy shares of and not just options?

>Please try to diversify

What like broad index tickers?  How about **$VTI**, and **$TOTL** then?

Or do you want a broad range of more specific index tickers?  One of the more amusing ones that no one else here will probably suggest is **$HMLSF** an **ETF** of marijuana stocks (not doing so well at the moment though relative to where it started).

**$GDX** is fun if you like high beta, but not the pure insanity of **$VIX**.

Or are you just looking for specific company stocks, like say **$TSLA**?
Hopeful for Red Hat ($RHT) and Arista Networks ($ANET) ... Not into Oracle, Microsoft, Apple, Google. I get enough of them in my VTI already.

I bought UDOW at 70ish this year. I made about 40% on target, and I've held googl since $650.

I also have about 60% of it in VTI, because I am a fan of indexing, and it's probably my go to lesson in investing when I'm telling someone about the wonderful world of asset growth.

Also I bought a bit of TTD that has given me +150%, I sold it though..

I'm very aggressive in my Roth, as it's one of the few ways to have tax advantaged growth
I just shorted VTI, maybe that was a good move.

Memes aside, don't waste time and start investing as soon as possible, even if you just put some spare money every month in whatever vanguard etf /r/personalfinance is recommending and don't touch it (actually, it's better if you just do that instead of gambling with options). Time is an advantage you have now and you'll never get back if you waste it.

When you want to buy a new iphone or something just buy 1000$ of VTI instead.

This is not financial advice or something
I mean to be fair VTI will actually make you money while playing with options will just make you broke

Man I'm just pissed right now. I've learned more about finance in my past 4 months by myself on this sub then I've learned in the past 3 1/2 years in my finance degree. The entirety of my semester long investments class boiled down to "put all your money into VTI". We skipped the entirety of derivatives because the prof said they are "too hard and confusing". My other finance courses have been a joke as well. I feel like I've just wasted my time. Now I'm trying to play with options because it makes me feel like a big finance boy.

"Robinhood makes trading fun and exciting- and that's part of the problem." 

what are they on with that? the translation for this should be "fuck you no fun allowed go buy VTI and wait until you die asshole."

Buy Shares of something $VTI or $TQQQ or $SSO  or $AMD $AAPL etc.  Don't do options at all. 

YOu will still make good on Shares when things jump too.

Also you will get margin if you put $25,000 into for example TD Ameritrade, you will get $100,000 on margin to spend on Shares.

Imagine now what you will make with $90,000 in Shares of Apple or AMD or etc.. 

Use that money on Shares with margin, not options. You will lose it with options. With shares you can just wait and you won't have to wait if you buy $90,000 of shares right after we have a huge minus Dow down 400-800 points day.

Just wait for the next big red day and then buy in slowly with like $5000 orders of shares at a time very slowly as it drops and buy more if it keeps dropping every other week.  

In 3-5 years you will have $250,000+ depending on which stock you went with and how low you bought it.


If you do do options, only do Vertical spread and/or Covered calls. that's it.
This is me with my large VTI and VOO positions and my $500 Robinhood options account.
